channel.title: Newb's Guide to HTML: by e0n™
channel.description: [center][size=18pt][b][u]™Noob's Guide to HTML™[/u] [i]by †e0n†™[/i][/b][/size][/center] [center][color=blue]Hello everyone and welcome to my guide. This guide was designed to assist brand new starters to HTML Code. We will be going from the very beggining, so if your not completetely new to HTML, the first couple of chapters will be [i]a little[/i] noobish. Well, I hope it helps![/center] [center][size=15pt]~ ~ ~[/size][/center] [center][b]Chapter 1: Introduction[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 2: Format[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 3: Text[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 4: Images[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 5: Links[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 6: Fonts[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 7: Basic Backrounds[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 8: Forms[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 9: Fonts[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 10: Buttons[/b][/center] [center][b]Chapter 11: Closing/Quiz/FAQ's[/b][/center] [center][size=15pt]~ ~ ~[/size][/center] [b]Chapter 1: Introduction[/b] HTML, short for Hypertext Markup Language, is the predominant markup language for the creation of web pages. It provides a means to describe the structure of text-based information in a document — by denoting certain text as headings, paragraphs, lists, and so on — and to supplement that text with interactive forms, embedded images, and other objects. HTML is written in the form of labels (known as tags), surrounded by less-than (<) and greater-than signs (>). HTML can also describe, to some degree, the appearance and semantics of a document, and can include embedded scripting language code which can affect the behavior of web browsers and other HTML processors. Confused? [b]Chapter 2: Format[/b] Alright in every html code you will ever see, there will be (1st) something like this: [code][/code] Okay, did you notice those, "<",">" things around it all? Well for now, we are going to refer to those "thingys" as "alliards." These alliards are around everything that will NOT be seen on your site. They designate what is code and what isn't. And when a alliard is ending something (ex. ) there is a "/" after the left alliard. This wraps up the end of that code started by: ex. [code][/code] Okay next, your going to see something like this, [code] Example[/code] What that is is the "" is like starting off the code. The "" is basically the same. The "" is what you see at the very top of your web browser in (for firefox & internet explorer) that blue bar. Usually there would be something in there like: "RuneScape - A online multiplayer adventure game by Jagex lmtd". Now at the end of the code it would say this: [code]</body></html>[/code] What this does is just wraps up the whole body of the code and ends with another "</html>". [b]Chapter 3: Text[/b] Okay, text. Text is what goes inside the codes. Here are some codes that manipulate text: 1. Bold Text = [code]<b>TEXTGOESHERE</b>[/code] 2. Skip a line down from other text = [code]<b>example</b> <br> <b> example </b>[/code] 3. Strong Text (makes text look "buffer", so to speak) = [code]<strong>TEXTGOESHERE</strong>[/code] 4. Big Text = [code]<big>TEXTGOESHERE</big>[/code] 5. Emphasized Text = [code]<em>TEXTGOESHERE</em>[/code] 6. Italic Text = [code]<i>TEXTGOESHERE</i>[/code] 7. Small Text = [code]<small>TEXTGOESHERE</small>[/code] 8. Subscript Text = [code]TEXTGOESHERE <sub> SUBSCRIPT TEXTGOESHERE </sub>[/code] 9. Superscript Text = [code]TEXTGOESHERE <sup> SUPERSCRIPT TEXTGOESHERE </sup>[/code] 10. Center Text = [code]<center>TEXTGOESHERE</center>[/code] 11. New Paragraph = [code]<p>text text text</p> <p>text text text</p>[/code] You will always need text if your ever coding a website. There are more text manipulating codes, but these are just the basics. [b]Chapter 4: Images[/b] Okay images are simple, here is a basic image code: [code]<img src="URLOFIMAGE" width="*number*" height="*number*">[/code] So every basic image has the, "<img src="URLOFIMAGE">, but not all have the, "width="144" height="50">". What that is the size of the image on your page. So if you were typing in some text and you wanted a image in the middle of your text it would look like: [code]text text <img src="URLOFIMAGE"> text text[/code] Also you can make images links, to do this use the following code: [code]<a href="http://www.YOURLINKHERE.com" target="_blank"><img src="URLOFIMAGE" border="0" alt="WHEREITTAKESYOU"></a>[/code] As you can see it has the basic image coding, but it also has some stuff before it, which is link code, next chapter. ;D [b]Chapter 5: Links[/b] Okay, Links are very simple. Here is the code for any basic word link: [code]<a href="http://www.YOURLINKHERE.com">DESCRIPTION</a>[/code] As you can see very simple. When you see "<a href=", it means the code has something to do with links. [b]Chapter 6: Fonts[/b] Okay, Fonts are also easy. Here is a basic font code: [code]<font size="YOURSIZEHERE" face="YOURFONTHERE"> YOURTEXTHERE </font>[/code] Now here is a table of basic font attributes (or size, font and color codes), (note that they are all examples): [IMG]http://i161.photobucket.com/albums/t217/b1ur67890/fontattributetable.jpg[/img] Okay, to use the font code here is how it would read: [code]<font size="YOURSIZEHERE" face="YOURFONTHERE"> YOURTEXTHERE>text text text text</font>[/code] [b]Chapter 7: Basic Backrounds[/b] Okay Backrounds are insanely easy! All you have to do is go to the top of your code, where it says, "<body>." Now replace "<body>" with this: [code]<body background="BACKROUND URL">[/code] No worries, if the backround image isn't big enough to fill the page, it will repeat itself, untill it fills it. I personally suggest pretty solid backround, so it makes text easy to read. [b]Chapter 8: Forms[/b] Heres an example of a basic form: [IMG]http://i161.photobucket.com/albums/t217/b1ur67890/basicform.jpg[/img] Okay, here is the code of that form: [code]<form action=""> First name: <input type="text" name="firstname"> <br> Last name: <input type="text" name="lastname"> </form>[/code] It is simple really, just replace "First name:" with what you want and same for Last name. Same thing for "firstname" and "lastname". Okay you now when you see a form, with username and password? And you know how for the password form, whatever you type is these things: *. Here the code to do that: [code]<form action=""> Username: <input type="text" name="user"> <br> Password: <input type="password" name="password"> </form>[/code] Thats basically it for forms! ;D [b]Chapter 9: Fonts[/b] Okay this is unrealistically easy. To change the font of text, you wrap the following code around it; [code]<font size="SIZENUMBER" face="EXAMPLE: Times"> TEXTGOESHERE </font>[/code] Thats it. Font size is where you put the number of your font size, and face is where you put the font. Usually you just use the first word of the font name. [b]Chapter 10: Buttons[/b] Okay basically what buttons are, are images that look like a button that is also a link. So what you need to do is make a image with photoshop preferably, and make it look like a button. So use that image for a code like this: [code]<a href="http://www.YOURLINKHERE.com" target="_blank"><img src="URLOFBUTTON IMAGE" border="0" alt="WHEREITTAKESYOU"></a>[/code] [b]Chapter 11: Closing/Quiz/FAQ's[/b] Well everyone, I hope this guide helped assist you with HTML. Now again (lol) if you alredy know HTML, this guide was noobish as all hell. But if you were a HTML starter, it was probably an answered prayer ;D. This guide was strictly made to educate people in the ways of HTML code so they can code their own webpages/sites. Thank you very much to read my guide and I hope it helped. [b]Sincerely,[/b] [i]e0n™[/i] [b]Quiz:[/b] Okay, this is a quiz to test you on how well you know HTML. Yes, there is all the answers listed above, but if you really want to test yourself, don't look. If you look, your really stupid, your just wasting your own time. Okay if you are taking the quiz, please post using this layout (note that layout will be in code, but do no re-post it in code, just the answers to questions that say: "post answer in code".): [code]Name: Date: 1. What is the code to insert a basic image? (post answer in code): 2. What is a alliard and what is it used for?: 3. What kind of code is the code; "a href=" used in?: 4. Multiple Choice Question: What code do you replace with another code in order to add a backround to your page? a) <html> b) <body> c) </html> d) <br> Answer: 5. What are the first 3 codes in the beginning of a code? (not including "]<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.example.com">" code) : Challenge (answer not above): 6. Do you really need this code in the beginning of your code? [code]]<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.example.com"> Answer: You have completed the Quiz! (delete this)[/code] [b]FAQ's[/b] [i]Coming Very Soon!!! (like tomorrow!)[/i] [center]Copyright 2007 ® That means if you steal this, I can sue bitch plus, if you steal it, Ill eat your kids [i]A e0n™ Original[/center][/code]

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.example.com">Yeah, that’s correct. If you’re gonna teach xHTML then this:

[code]

Example[/code] Is incorrect. You have to close the head tag before the body tag, and have the title tag embedded in the head tags ex: [code] [b][/b] Hi [b][/b] jdoisfjd [/code]

item.title: Newb's Guide to HTML: by e0n™
item.dc:creator: @e0n e0n™
item.description:
@e0n wrote:

[center][size=18pt]™Noob’s Guide to HTML™
by †e0n†™[/size][/center]

[center][color=blue]Hello everyone and welcome to my guide. This guide was designed to assist brand new starters to HTML Code. We will be going from the very beggining, so if your not completetely new to HTML, the first couple of chapters will be a little noobish. Well, I hope it helps![/center]

[center][size=15pt]~ ~ ~[/size][/center]

[center]Chapter 1: Introduction[/center]
[center]Chapter 2: Format[/center]
[center]Chapter 3: Text[/center]
[center]Chapter 4: Images[/center]
[center]Chapter 5: Links[/center]
[center]Chapter 6: Fonts[/center]
[center]Chapter 7: Basic Backrounds[/center]
[center]Chapter 8: Forms[/center]
[center]Chapter 9: Fonts[/center]
[center]Chapter 10: Buttons[/center]
[center]Chapter 11: Closing/Quiz/FAQ’s[/center]

[center][size=15pt]~ ~ ~[/size][/center]

Chapter 1: Introduction

HTML, short for Hypertext Markup Language, is the predominant markup language for the creation of web pages. It provides a means to describe the structure of text-based information in a document — by denoting certain text as headings, paragraphs, lists, and so on — and to supplement that text with interactive forms, embedded images, and other objects. HTML is written in the form of labels (known as tags), surrounded by less-than (<) and greater-than signs (>). HTML can also describe, to some degree, the appearance and semantics of a document, and can include embedded scripting language code which can affect the behavior of web browsers and other HTML processors. Confused?

Chapter 2: Format

Alright in every html code you will ever see, there will be (1st) something like this:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.example.com">

Okay, did you notice those, “<”,">" things around it all? Well for now, we are going to refer to those “thingys” as “alliards.” These alliards are around everything that will NOT be seen on your site. They designate what is code and what isn’t. And when a alliard is ending something (ex. ) there is a “/” after the left alliard. This wraps up the end of that code started by: ex.

<example>

Okay next, your going to see something like this,

[code]

Example[/code]

What that is is the “” is like starting off the code. The “” is basically the same. The “” is what you see at the very top of your web browser in (for firefox & internet explorer) that blue bar. Usually there would be something in there like: “RuneScape - A online multiplayer adventure game by Jagex lmtd”.

Now at the end of the code it would say this:

</body></html>

What this does is just wraps up the whole body of the code and ends with another “”.

Chapter 3: Text

Okay, text. Text is what goes inside the codes. Here are some codes that manipulate text:

  1. Bold Text =
<b>TEXTGOESHERE</b>
  1. Skip a line down from other text =

[code]example


example [/code]
  1. Strong Text (makes text look “buffer”, so to speak) =
<strong>TEXTGOESHERE</strong>
  1. Big Text =
<big>TEXTGOESHERE</big>
  1. Emphasized Text =
<em>TEXTGOESHERE</em>
  1. Italic Text =
<i>TEXTGOESHERE</i>
  1. Small Text =
<small>TEXTGOESHERE</small>
  1. Subscript Text =

TEXTGOESHERE <sub> SUBSCRIPT TEXTGOESHERE </sub>

  1. Superscript Text =

TEXTGOESHERE <sup> SUPERSCRIPT TEXTGOESHERE </sup>

  1. Center Text =
<center>TEXTGOESHERE</center>
  1. New Paragraph =

[code]

text text text

text text text

[/code]

You will always need text if your ever coding a website. There are more text manipulating codes, but these
are just the basics.

Chapter 4: Images

Okay images are simple, here is a basic image code:

<img src="URLOFIMAGE" width="*number*" height="*number*">

So every basic image has the, ", but not all have the, “width=“144” height=“50”>”. What that is the size of the image on your page. So if you were typing in some text and you wanted a image in the middle of your text it would look like:

text text <img src="URLOFIMAGE"> text text

Also you can make images links, to do this use the following code:

<a href="http://www.YOURLINKHERE.com" target="_blank"><img src="URLOFIMAGE" border="0" alt="WHEREITTAKESYOU"></a>

As you can see it has the basic image coding, but it also has some stuff before it, which is link code, next chapter. ;D

Chapter 5: Links

Okay, Links are very simple. Here is the code for any basic word link:

<a href="http://www.YOURLINKHERE.com">DESCRIPTION</a>

As you can see very simple. When you see “<a href=”, it means the code has something to do with links.

Chapter 6: Fonts

Okay, Fonts are also easy. Here is a basic font code:

<font size="YOURSIZEHERE" face="YOURFONTHERE"> YOURTEXTHERE </font>

Now here is a table of basic font attributes (or size, font and color codes), (note that they are all examples):

Okay, to use the font code here is how it would read:

<font size="YOURSIZEHERE" face="YOURFONTHERE"> YOURTEXTHERE>text text text text</font>

Chapter 7: Basic Backrounds

Okay Backrounds are insanely easy! All you have to do is go to the top of your code, where it says, “.” Now replace “” with this:

<body background="BACKROUND URL">

No worries, if the backround image isn’t big enough to fill the page, it will repeat itself, untill it fills it.

I personally suggest pretty solid backround, so it makes text easy to read.

Chapter 8: Forms

Heres an example of a basic form:

Okay, here is the code of that form:

[code]
First name:



Last name:

[/code]

It is simple really, just replace “First name:” with what you want and same for Last name. Same thing for “firstname” and “lastname”.

Okay you now when you see a form, with username and password? And you know how for the password form, whatever you type is these things: *. Here the code to do that:

[code]
Username:



Password:

[/code]

Thats basically it for forms! ;D

Chapter 9: Fonts

Okay this is unrealistically easy. To change the font of text, you wrap the following code around it;

<font size="SIZENUMBER" face="EXAMPLE: Times"> TEXTGOESHERE </font>

Thats it. Font size is where you put the number of your font size, and face is where you put the font. Usually you just use the first word of the font name.

Chapter 10: Buttons

Okay basically what buttons are, are images that look like a button that is also a link. So what you need to do is make a image with photoshop preferably, and make it look like a button. So use that image for a code like this:

<a href="http://www.YOURLINKHERE.com" target="_blank"><img src="URLOFBUTTON IMAGE" border="0" alt="WHEREITTAKESYOU"></a>

Chapter 11: Closing/Quiz/FAQ’s

Well everyone, I hope this guide helped assist you with HTML. Now again (lol) if you alredy know HTML, this guide was noobish as all hell. But if you were a HTML starter, it was probably an answered
prayer ;D. This guide was strictly made to educate people in the ways of HTML code so they can code their own webpages/sites. Thank you very much to read my guide and I hope it helped.

Sincerely,
e0n™

Quiz:

Okay, this is a quiz to test you on how well you know HTML. Yes, there is all the answers listed above, but if you really want to test yourself, don’t look. If you look, your really stupid, your just wasting your own time.

Okay if you are taking the quiz, please post using this layout (note that layout will be in code, but do no re-post it in code, just the answers to questions that say: “post answer in code”.):

[code]Name:

Date:

  1. What is the code to insert a basic image? (post answer in code):

  2. What is a alliard and what is it used for?:

  3. What kind of code is the code; “a href=” used in?:

  4. Multiple Choice Question: What code do you replace with another code in order to add a backround to your page?

a)

b)

c)

d)

Answer:

  1. What are the first 3 codes in the beginning of a code? (not including “]” code) :

Challenge (answer not above): 6. Do you really need this code in the beginning of your code?

[code]]

Answer:

You have completed the Quiz! (delete this)[/code]
